Package xtc.type Description

xtc's representation of types. This package defines a hierarchy of type classes, representing types of the C, Java, and ML programming languages as well as pseudo-types to help with type-checking programs. In particular:
  • Type is the superclass of all type classes and defines the common interface.
  • VoidT represents the void type.
  • UnitT represents the unit type.
  • BooleanT represents the boolean type.
  • IntegerT and FloatT represent integer and floating point numbers, respectively.
  • InternalT represents compiler-internal types, such as the __builtin_va_list type used by gcc for variable argument lists.
  • LabelT and PackageT represent labels and packages, respectively.
  • PointerT, ArrayT, StructT, UnionT, FunctionT, MethodT, ClassT, InterfaceT, TupleT, and VariantT represent derived types.
  • WrappedT is the superclass of pseudo-types adding symbolic information to any of the previous types. AliasT represents type aliases; AnnotatedT provides annotations for another type; EnumeratorT and EnumT represent C enums; VariableT represents globals, locals, fields, and bitfields; ParameterizedT represents parameterized types; and InstantiatedT represents instantiations of parameterized types.
  • Parameter represents a type parameter and Wildcard represents a wildcard. Types containing instances of these classes are parameterized. They should be wrapped in a ParameterizedT and instantiated through a InstantiatedT.
  • Finally, ErrorT represents typing errors.
These type classes are complemented by a common interface for all tagged types (structs, unions, and enums) and for all constant-valued types (enumerators and the ConstantT pseudo-type).

To model the memory shape of lvalues, this package also defines a separate hierarchy of references:

  • Reference is the superclass of all reference classes and defines the common interface. All references have a type specifying the referenced memory's shape or layout.
  • NullReference.NULL represents the zero location in memory. It has void as its type.
  • StaticReference and DynamicReference represent statically and dynamically allocated variables, respectively. Both reference classes are symbolic representations of memory; they do not have a known location.
  • RelativeReference is the superclass of all relative references, with each relative reference having another reference as its base.
  • CastReference represents a differently typed view on the same memory region.
  • IndirectReference represents an indirection through a memory region, i.e., pointer.
  • IndexReference represents an integer offset from another reference, while FieldReference represents a symbolic offset.
